CONCLUSION: Violations of Art. 5-4;Violation of Art. 5-5;Violation of Art. 13+8;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG commenced a criminal investigation into a suspicious money transfer CARDINAL bank accounts .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Prosecutor General ruled that the investigation should be supervised by ORG . It was observed that the suspected offence had been committed in the region of LOC and that the Prešov Regional Prosecutor would normally have had jurisdiction to deal with it . It was , however , presumed that the offence had been part of a larger criminal transaction involving several individuals in various places and requiring extensive investigation . In order to ensure the effectiveness and expeditious determination of the proceedings , it was necessary to transfer jurisdiction to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Prosecutor General took a similar measure in respect of an investigation into irregularities in insolvency proceedings concerning bank A.

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and CARDINAL other individuals were charged with conspiracy and embezzlement on suspicion of having fraudulently and in an organised fashion drained money from the insolvency estate of A.
The applicant for his part was suspected of having organised a bank transfer of the money in question . The decision was based on “ previously obtained testimonies and documentary evidence ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was placed in detention pending trial . He remained detained until his release on DATE . The circumstances and decisions relating to his detention are described in paragraphs CARDINAL below .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation in question was joined to inquiries in CARDINAL other cases concerning murders which had connections with the insolvency proceedings in respect of bank A.

CARDINAL . After the investigation had been completed , the applicant was invited to inspect the investigation file . He did so on DATE and DATE . He discovered , inter alia , that the file contained information which had been obtained by monitoring his telephone calls . This information comprised the transcript of a specific phone call from the applicant ’s mobile telephone and a list of outgoing and incoming calls in a specific period .

CARDINAL . The applicant unsuccessfully complained to the prosecution service and ORG that the monitoring of his telephone communications had been unlawful and unjustified . The details concerning his constitutional complaint are set out in DATE and DATE below .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Trenčín Regional Prosecutor indicted the applicant and committed him to stand trial before the Prešov Regional Court ( Krajský súd ) on charges of conspiracy and embezzlement . The indictment was also directed against CARDINAL other individuals , including CARDINAL lawyers , and included charges of money laundering , murder and illegal possession of firearms .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ruled that the case fell within the jurisdiction of ORG ) , which had been established a short time before in order to try cases involving corruption , organised crime and other serious offences . Both the applicant and the prosecution service challenged this ruling .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) upheld the jurisdiction of ORG . The applicant then unsuccessfully challenged this decision before ORG , which rejected his constitutional complaint on DATE , and before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was transferred to ORG , which decided , on DATE , to hive off the applicant ’s trial to a separate set of proceedings .

CARDINAL . Following a judgment of ORG DATE finding that the legislation establishing ORG was contrary to LAW and the subsequent replacement of that court by a newly established ORG ( Špecializovaný trestný súd ) ( for details see PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , the applicant ’s trial was transferred to the latter court and it is still pending there .
CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , the applicant was arrested on charges which had been brought on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , the regional prosecutor lodged a request with ORG súd ) that the applicant and the other suspects be placed in detention pending trial .

CARDINAL . On TIME DATE the applicant ’s brother appointed a lawyer to represent the applicant . At TIME FAC , in whose custody the applicant was at that time , refused the lawyer access to the applicant .
CARDINAL . On TIME DATE the lawyer and the applicant met for TIME .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , ORG opened a hearing on the prosecutor ’s request . CARDINAL by one , the suspects were questioned . The applicant was questioned in the presence of his lawyer . Neither of them had access to the case file . At TIME FAC ordered the detention of the applicant and the other suspects pending trial .

CARDINAL . ORG found that there was a well - founded suspicion against the accused . The investigation was in its initial stages and there was still much evidence to be gathered . This , together with the “ character and circumstances of the offence ” , gave rise to fears that the suspects would collude within the meaning of LAW ( b ) of LAW ( “ the ORG ” ) . Furthermore , the information available indicated that other criminal offences had been committed in connection with the insolvency of bank PERSON accused were suspected of having been involved in those offences . This prompted fears that the accused would continue criminal activities within the meaning of LAW ( c ) of the ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an interlocutory appeal ( sťažnosť ) against his detention and on DATE he adduced further grounds of appeal .

He argued first of all that ORG had no territorial jurisdiction to decide on his detention . The court competent to do so had been the court in the judicial district where the offence had purportedly been committed .

The applicant further argued that he had not had adequate time and facilities to confer with his lawyer and to prepare his defence . Both the prosecutor ’s proposal and the decision on detention had been so vague that it had been impossible to mount any meaningful defence .

The applicant went on to argue that the suspicion against him had been ill - founded and that there had been no admissible evidence in support of it . There had been no reasons for detaining him and the decision had lacked adequate reasoning .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting in private ( neverejné zasadnutie ) , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . In summary reasoning , it simply referred to and fully concurred with ORG reasons for detention . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , the applicant ’s lawyer had unsuccessfully requested access to the case file on several occasions .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint under LAW with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) .

He challenged the above - mentioned decisions concerning his detention and claimed a violation of a number of his procedural rights . The applicant complained that : ( i ) the court which had issued the detention order had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter ; ( ii ) he had not had adequate time and facilities to confer with his lawyer and prepare his defence ; ( iii ) he and his lawyers had been refused access to the case file ; ( iv ) there had been no reasonable suspicion against him and no reason for detaining him ; ( v ) the decisions had lacked adequate reasoning ; and ( vi ) the proceedings had been too lengthy .
The applicant sought a ruling setting aside the impugned decisions , releasing him and awarding him damages .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaint concerning the refusal of access to the case file , and the remaining complaints inadmissible .

CARDINAL . As to the inadmissible complaints , ORG observed that the territorial jurisdiction of ORG had been based on LAW ORG , pursuant to which territorial jurisdiction in matters concerning the preparatory stage of proceedings was vested in the court in the judicial district in which the prosecutor acted . The offences of which the applicant was suspected and the reasons for his detention had been stated and had been adequately explained .

The applicant had known as far back as DATE how much time he had had to consult his lawyer . His constitutional complaint alleging that the time had been insufficient had been made in DATE that is to say , outside the statutory DATE time - limit .
The length of the proceedings in respect of the applicant ’s detention had been acceptable , given that the applicant had not fully specified his appeal until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered a judgment ( nález ) on the merits of the admissible complaint . It held that the absolute refusal of access to the case file had been incompatible with LAW . However , this had had no material impact on the lawfulness and constitutionality of the detention as such . That finding was therefore sufficient compensation for any non - pecuniary damage the applicant might have sustained .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for release or , alternatively , for his detention to be replaced by a pledge LAW ORG that he would live in accordance with the law .
CARDINAL . By law the requests fell to be determined first by the regional prosecutor , who dismissed them , and , on DATE , forwarded them ex officio to ORG for judicial determination .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting in a private session , rejected the request for release . “ Having examined the applicant ’s request and the case file ” , ORG “ established that the reasons for the applicant ’s detention persisted ” . The offences under investigation were very serious . The investigation had been carried out on a large scale and with due diligence , and given that it was in its early stages there was a well - founded fear that the applicant would collude with the other suspects and continue criminal activities .

ORG made no formal ruling in respect of the alternative proposal to replace the applicant ’s detention with a pledge of lawful conduct . It merely observed in its reasoning that such a move was not possible if a person stood accused of such offences as the applicant did . The applicant lodged an interlocutory appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting in private , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . In summary reasoning it simply referred to and fully concurred with the reasons given by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged the decisions of CARDINAL May and DATE and the proceedings leading to them by means of a constitutional complaint . He alleged a violation of several of his procedural rights .

CARDINAL . As in his previous complaint , the applicant objected that : ( i ) the court deciding on his detention had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter ; ( ii ) there had been an irregularity in the assignment of his appeal for determination by a specific chamber at ORG ; ( iii ) the decision - making process had been conducted in private and the applicant had had no opportunity to state his case orally ; ( iv ) neither he nor his lawyer had been granted access to the case file ; ( v ) the decisions had been arbitrary , ( vi ) had lacked proper reasoning and ( vii ) had been the outcome of proceedings that had not been speedy ; ( viii ) finally , the total duration of the applicant ’s detention had been excessive and ( ix ) the courts had failed to take a formal decision in respect of his petition for his detention to be replaced by a pledge of lawful conduct .
The applicant sought a ruling that the challenged decisions be set aside and claimed CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) in damages .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant supplemented his constitutional complaint by arguing that his detention was unlawful on the ground that , when it had begun , he had not been brought before a judge within DATE TIME required by LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) ( PERSON základných práv a slobôd – “ the LAW ” ) .

It was true that the time - limit for bringing an arrested person before a judge under LAW of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) , as amended with effect from DATE ( Constitutional Law no . PERSON . ) , was TIME . However , neither the LAW nor any other legislation had repealed the LAW expressly and implicit repeal was not permissible . The LAW guaranteed him a broader extent of legal protection and had to be applied in his case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaints listed under ( ii ) , ( iv ) and ( vi ) - ( ix ) above . The remaining complaints were declared inadmissible for the following reasons .
CARDINAL . NORP The issue of the territorial jurisdiction of ORG had already been examined and determined in ORG decision of DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL above ) .

The applicant had had ample opportunity to present his case in writing and with the assistance of a lawyer , and had in fact done so at length . The lack of an oral hearing therefore raised no issue under LAW .

The applicant ’s continued detention was , as such , justified and lawful . As to the discrepancy between the time - limits for bringing an arrested person before a judge under LAW ( TIME ) and LAW ( TIME ) , ORG held that , pursuant to LAW , the constitutional provision prevailed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered a judgment on the merits of the admissible complaints .

ORG found that there had been a violation of the applicant ’s right under LAW to a trial within a reasonable time or release pending trial , in that the courts had failed to take a formal decision on his request for his detention to be replaced by a pledge of lawful conduct .

ORG also found that there had been a violation of the applicant ’s rights under LAW , in that : the applicant ’s appeal had been determined by the wrong chamber of ORG ; the applicant had been refused access to the case file ; and the proceedings had not been speedy .
The applicant was awarded SKK CARDINAL by way of compensation for non - pecuniary damage , and had his legal costs reimbursed .
CARDINAL . The complaint that the impugned decisions lacked proper reasoning was dismissed as unfounded .

CARDINAL . On DATE the regional prosecutor requested that ORG authorise an extension of the detention of the applicant and all his co - defendants until DATE . Neither the applicant nor his lawyer was informed of the request .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in a private session , ORG acceded to the prosecutor ’s request . Neither the applicant nor his lawyer was informed of the session .

CARDINAL . “ Having examined the prosecutor ’s request and the case file ” , the ORG “ established that the request was well founded ” . Although the investigation had been carried out with due diligence , it had not been possible to complete it within DATE which had elapsed from the start of the applicant ’s detention . The reasons for keeping the defendants in detention , as established at the time of the detention order , still persisted . Their release might render the investigation and the whole proceedings difficult or even impossible . No appeal lay against the decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer phoned ORG and was informed that , on CARDINAL DATE , the regional prosecutor had requested an extension of the applicant ’s detention . On DATE the lawyer requested in writing that ORG provide him with a copy of the request .
CARDINAL . Copies of the decision of DATE and of the prosecutor ’s request were served on the applicant ’s lawyer on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged the decision of DATE by means of a constitutional complaint .

He argued in the main ( i ) that the court deciding on the extension of his detention had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter ; ( ii ) that the prosecutor ’s request had not been made available to him in good time ; ( iii ) that he had consequently had no opportunity to comment on it and to state his case orally ( the decision had been made in private ) ; and ( iv ) that the decision had been arbitrary and unjustified .
DATE . On DATE the applicant supplemented his complaint by submitting substantially the same arguments as in his submission of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaint that the extension of the applicant ’s detention had been arbitrary and unjustified and declared the remaining complaints inadmissible . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . As to the inadmissible complaints , ORG observed that the issue of territorial jurisdiction of ORG had already been examined and determined in ORG decision of DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL above ) .

Under applicable law , there had been no legal duty to communicate a copy of the prosecutor ’s request for extension of detention to the person concerned . The applicant ’s lawyer ought to have known that , pursuant to LAW ORG , a request for an extension of a person ’s detention had to be submitted to the competent court DATE before the expiry of their detention . In the present case the deadline had been DATE .
However , the applicant ’s lawyer had not contacted the prosecution service until DATE and his failure to do so at an earlier date could not be imputed to the authorities .

The fact that the decision had been made in a private session was irrelevant because the prosecution service had also not been able to take part in that session . As to the discrepancy between the time - limits for bringing an arrested person before a judge under LAW and the LAW , the court found that it had had no relevance to the decision in question and , moreover , had been raised as an issue outside the statutory DATE timelimit .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that there had been a violation of the applicant ’s rights under LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW , in that the decision of DATE had lacked adequate reasoning . The decision in question had contained a detailed description of the charges , the nature of which had themselves constituted a part of the reason for the applicant ’s detention . However , the charges had concerned a group of suspects and it had not been clear from the charges which reasons for detention pertained to which suspects . Although such reasoning had been sufficient to detain the applicant in the initial stage of the proceedings , it had not been sufficiently detailed DATE into the proceedings .
ORG remarked that this conclusion had no impact on whether the applicant ’s detention after DATE had or had not been justified in substance .
It quashed the decision of DATE and awarded the applicant SKK CARDINAL in compensation for non - pecuniary damage . It also reimbursed his legal costs .
As the applicant had been released in the meantime , there was no question of ordering ORG to determine the matter anew .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for release or , alternatively , for his detention to be replaced by a pledge of lawful conduct . He argued that most of the relevant evidence had already been taken and examined and that it had shown that he was innocent and that there were no reasons for detaining him .
CARDINAL . NORP The regional prosecutor dismissed the applicant ’s requests and , on DATE , forwarded them to ORG for judicial determination .

CARDINAL . The applicant challenged the handling of the proceedings by the regional prosecutor – in particular , the length of such examination – by means of a constitutional complaint ( for the outcome see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in a private session , ORG rejected the application for release . “ Having examined the applicant ’s request and the relevant files ” , ORG “ established that the reasons for the applicant ’s detention persisted ” . It held specifically that there were a number of pieces of evidence which had been secured in the preparatory stage of the proceedings and which still had to be examined by the court . The way in which the suspected offence had supposedly been committed had prompted fears that the applicant would tamper with that evidence .

CARDINAL . ORG again made no ruling in respect of the alternative proposal to replace the applicant ’s detention with a pledge of lawful conduct , observing that such a replacement could only be considered in connection with detention to prevent escape ( LAW ) of the ORG ) , which was not applicable to the applicant ’s case . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in a private session , ORG upheld the above - mentioned decision rejecting the applicant ’s request for release .

At the same time , it ruled that his detention was no longer justified by fears that he would continue criminal activities but merely by the fear that he would collude with other defendants . That concern stemmed from the “ manner in which the offence had been committed and covered up and from the status of the accused ” . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged another constitutional complaint , directed in the main against the actions and decisions of ORG and ORG .
He again argued that the courts deciding on his detention had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter .

Furthermore , he complained that the assignment of his request for release to a ORG judge had not followed the procedure prescribed by law . In particular , the request had not been treated as an independent matter , which should have been randomly assigned to a judge through electronic means , but rather had been assigned to a specific judge who had been administratively designated by the President of ORG to deal with all matters concerning the applicant .

Moreover , the courts had not held a hearing and had thus deprived the applicant of the chance to plead his case . The decisions had been arbitrary and had lacked proper reasoning . The length of his detention had been excessive .

CARDINAL . On DATE , by way of CARDINAL separate decisions , ORG declared admissible the complaint against ORG and inadmissible the complaint against ORG and ORG . The latter decision was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . As to the inadmissible complaint , ORG observed that under the applicable procedural rules , the decision of ORG of DATE had become final and binding on DATE . Notwithstanding that the decision had not been served until DATE , the relevant date for commencement of the statutory DATE period for lodging a constitutional complaint had been CARDINAL DATE . The complaint against ORG and ORG had been submitted on DATE , and had therefore been out of time .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that ORG had violated the applicant ’s right under LAW to a speedy decision concerning his detention , in that it had taken DATE for the prosecutor to take a decision in relation to the applicant ’s requests of DATE and to forward them to ORG .

ORG took into account the fact that the proceedings concerning those requests had lasted a total of DATE before the final decision was served . It granted the applicant reimbursement of his legal costs but no compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage . ORG held that it was not appropriate to order the prosecution service to compensate the applicant for any non - pecuniary damage , as the prosecution service ’s share of responsibility for the overall duration of those proceedings was minor compared to that of the ordinary courts .

CARDINAL . On DATE the regional prosecutor requested that ORG authorise an extension of the detention of the applicant and all his co - defendants until DATE . No copy of the request was served on the applicant or his lawyer .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s lawyer obtained a copy of the prosecutor ’s request on his own initiative and , on DATE , the applicant filed his observations in reply . On DATE , in a separate submission , the applicant challenged ORG for bias .

The applicant complained , inter alia , that the prosecutor ’s request had not been lawfully and randomly assigned to a judge through electronic means but rather had been assigned administratively by the President of ORG to another judge following the departure of the judge electronically assigned from that court .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in a private session , ORG dismissed the challenge of bias and authorised an extension of the detention of all the defendants until DATE . It held that there were still a number of pieces of evidence to be examined by the court and that , if released , the applicant would pose a risk of interfering with such evidence . However , the time frame demanded by the prosecution was excessive and an extension until DATE had to suffice .

CARDINAL . The decision of CARDINAL DATE stated that no appeal lay against it . The applicant nevertheless appealed and his appeal was dismissed by ORG on DATE . That decision was served on him on DATE .

ORG acknowledged , inter alia , that assignment of cases to judges at ORG was in principle to be carried out randomly through electronic means . In the applicant ’s case , the judge electronically assigned had been appointed to ORG . It had consequently been the responsibility of the President of ORG to reassign the applicant ’s case to another judge , which she had lawfully done .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint , to which he added further grounds of complaint on DATE and CARDINAL DATE . He argued : ( i ) that the QUANTITY period under the LAW for bringing him before a judge had not been observed ; ( ii ) that the court deciding on the extension of his detention had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter ; ( iii ) that it had not been impartial ; ( iv ) that the prosecutor ’s request of DATE had not been served on him and that he had been obliged to procure a copy of it himself ; ( v ) that there had been no public hearing of his case and that he had been unable to plead his case ; ( vi ) that the extension of his detention had been arbitrary and ( vii ) had lacked proper reasoning ; ( viii ) that the proceedings in respect of his detention had not been speedy ; and ( ix ) that the total duration of his detention had been excessive .
The applicant claimed SKK CARDINAL in compensation for nonpecuniary damage .
DATE . On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaints listed under ( iv ) , ( v ) , ( vii ) ; ( viii ) and ( ix ) above . The remaining complaints were declared inadmissible .

CARDINAL . As to the inadmissible complaints , ORG observed that the applicant had learned in DATE that the extension of his detention would be determined by ORG . He had raised his complaint in that respect before ORG in DATE that is to say , outside the statutory twomonth time - limit .
The complaint concerning delays in dealing with the prosecutor ’s request before ORG had also been submitted out of time .
The proceedings before ORG had ended with its decision of CARDINAL DATE , which the applicant had learned of no later than DATE that is , DATE before he had lodged his complaint .

The scope of ORG review of the factual and legal conclusions of the ordinary courts was limited to constitutionally relevant errors , and the decisions concerning the impartiality of the ORG judges and the extension of the applicant ’s detention fell outside the scope of that review .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the fact that the prosecutor ’s request of DATE had not been served on the applicant had violated his rights under LAW .

ORG allowed a small part of the applicant ’s claim for reimbursement of his legal costs and dismissed his claim for compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage . ORG considered that such an award was not appropriate because the ordinary courts had conducted the proceedings in accordance with the existing statutory rules .

CARDINAL . The remaining admissible complaints were also dismissed . ORG found the reasons which had been given by the courts for extending the detention to be adequate and that the extended detention had been justified . The length of the proceedings concerning the extension of the applicant ’s detention had been acceptable , in particular , in view of the factual and legal complexity of the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for release and , alternatively , for his detention to be replaced by a pledge of lawful conduct .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s requests and forwarded them , with a comment , to ORG for judicial determination .

It was later established that , in his comment , the prosecutor opposed the applicant ’s request “ with reference to [ his ] arguments in the [ second ] request for extension of the applicant ’s detention ” . The comment had not been made available to the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged ORG for lack of territorial jurisdiction in the matter and the ORG judges involved in his case for bias .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE respectively , ORG and , on appeal , ORG , dismissed the request for release . Both decisions were made in private , the latter being served on the applicant on DATE . The courts made no separate ruling concerning the applicant ’s alternative request , merely observing in their reasoning that , in the circumstances , the request was not legally permissible .

The courts concluded that the territorial jurisdiction of ORG to deal with the case had been based on LAW ORG , and observed that the applicant ’s challenge on the ground of bias had already been examined and dismissed in connection with the second extension of his detention ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

The courts held that the available evidence had borne out the suspicion against the applicant . The manner in which the offence had been committed and covered up , combined with the fact that some additional evidence still had to be examined by the trial court , gave rise to a fear that the applicant would collude with other defendants . His continued detention was therefore justified .

DATE . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint , which he fully specified on CARDINAL DATE . He contended : ( i ) that his detention had been illegal ab initio , in that the time - limit of TIME for bringing him before a judge under the LAW had not been complied with ; ( ii ) that the courts deciding on his detention had had no territorial jurisdiction in the matter and had been biased ; ( iii ) that the observations by the prosecution service in reply to his request for release had not been communicated to him ; ( iv ) that the courts had held no hearing in relation to his application and that he had not been heard in person ; ( v ) that the courts had failed to take a decision in relation to his alternative proposal and that his continued detention was unjustified ; ( vi ) that the courts’ decisions had lacked adequate reasoning ; and ( vii ) that the proceedings had not been speedy .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaints under points ( iii ) DATE ( vii ) . The remaining complaints were declared inadmissible .

CARDINAL . As to the inadmissible complaints , ORG observed that the applicant had learned in DATE that the extension of his detention would be determined by ORG . He had raised his complaint before ORG in DATE that is , outside the statutory DATE time - limit .

The complaint concerning delays in dealing with the prosecutor ’s request before ORG had also been submitted out of time . The proceedings before ORG had ended with its decision on DATE , which the applicant had learned of no later than DATE that is , DATE before he had lodged the constitutional complaint . In any event , the complaints concerning the territorial jurisdiction and impartiality of the courts had been repetitive of earlier complaints and had warranted no fresh examination .

Lastly , as to the twenty - four - hour time - limit under the LAW , ORG observed that the LAW took precedence over all other legislation and that the time - limit of TIME under the LAW had been observed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the courts’ failure to take a decision in relation to the applicant ’s alternative proposal to replace his detention by a pledge of lawful conduct had violated his rights under LAW . Furthermore , ORG found that the ORG failure to ensure that a copy of the prosecutor ’s comment in reply to the applicant ’s requests of CARDINAL DATE had been served on the applicant had violated his rights under LAW . The applicant was granted a small part of his claim for reimbursement of his legal costs , but no compensation in respect of nonpecuniary damage . ORG considered that such an award was not appropriate because , inter alia , the ordinary courts had conducted the proceedings in accordance with the applicable statutory rules .

CARDINAL . The remaining admissible complaints were dismissed . The applicant had had , and in fact had made full use of , the chance to present his case in writing and with legal assistance . In the light of this fact , the lack of a hearing had entailed no substantial ramifications for his rights . The suspicion against the applicant and the danger of collusion had been established ; the investigation was ongoing and expeditious ; the applicant ’s continued detention had been justified . As to the length of the proceedings concerning the applicant ’s request for release , in line with its decision on the admissibility of the present complaint , ORG reviewed only that part of the proceedings which had taken place before ORG . It found no lack of speed in relation to their determination .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint alleging that the monitoring of his telephone calls had been unlawful , arbitrary and unjustified . He relied , inter alia , on LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible for non - exhaustion of ordinary remedies .
It came to the conclusion that the applicant was entitled to raise an objection against the evidence obtained from the monitoring in the course of the ongoing criminal proceedings against him .
If the applicant did so , the courts would have to examine whether that evidence had been obtained lawfully . The ordinary courts’ power of review excluded a review by ORG .
ORG further concluded that the applicant could seek redress under civil law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a request under section CARDINAL of LAW DATE with ORG for payment of SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL by way of compensation in respect of unlawful detention . He relied on ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph DATE above ) .
CARDINAL . As ORG had failed to respond , on DATE the applicant lodged the claim with ORG .

CARDINAL . In observations of CARDINAL DATE the ORG submitted that , under section CARDINAL ) of the LAW , any compensation for wrongful detention only came into question where the prosecution had been dropped or the person concerned had been acquitted , none of which was the case as regards the applicant . As the charges against the applicant had not been dropped , neither could he be compensated under section PERSON ) of the LAW for wrongful prosecution .
CARDINAL . On DATE the action was stayed pending the outcome of the applicant ’s criminal trial .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions and judicial practice are summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of GPE and GPE ( nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , § § DATE and DATE , DATE ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE to CARDINAL , DATE and DATE , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions are summarised in the ORG ’s judgments in the cases of GPE and PERSON GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions are summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of GPE and PERSON GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) ; PERSON GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The applicable rules are summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of GPE and PERSON GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) ; GPE v. GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions and judicial practice are summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of GPE and PERSON GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) ; PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . By its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in an appeal on points of law ( no . CARDINAL Cdo CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) concerning an action for damages under LAW DATE , ORG upheld the view that neither that LAW nor an action for protection of personal integrity provided a legal basis for awarding compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage caused by unlawful detention .
LAW DATE was , however , to be interpreted in line with LAW which presupposed compensation for nonpecuniary damage and which , pursuant to LAW , prevailed over the statutory text .

CARDINAL . The relevant statutory provisions and further judicial practice are summarised in PERSON v. GPE ( cited above , § § DATE ) ; GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) ; Pavletić v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE ( ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant statutory provisions and judicial practice are summarised in GPE v. GPE ( DATE . ) , no . DATE , DATE ) , PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE ( extracts ) ) , GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) , PERSON v. GPE ( no . GPE , § § DATE , DATE ) , GPE v. GPE ( ( dec . ) no . GPE , DATE ) , PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALVIII ) , PERSON v. GPE ( cited above ( dec . ) , DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE ( DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . ORG has dealt with monitoring of telephone communications in cases nos . IV . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON . ÚS DATE , II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL and III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . ORG declared inadmissible cases no . IV . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on DATE ) , no . IV . ÚS DATE ( on DATE ) , no . II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on DATE ) and no . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on CARDINAL DATE ) because the complainants had had , but had not used , the chance to challenge in their criminal trials evidence obtained by monitoring telephone communications and/or because the complaints were manifestly ill - founded .

In none of those cases did the Constitutional Court require the complainants to seek protection of their rights and interests by way of an action for protection of personal integrity for the purposes of exhaustion of ordinary remedies under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . In cases nos . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on DATE ) , PERSON CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on CARDINAL DATE ) , and III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( on DATE ) , ORG found a violation of the ORG rights and freedoms under LAW and the Convention on account of monitoring their telephone communications and awarded them compensation in respect of nonpecuniary damage .

In none of those cases is there any indication that the complainants had sought protection of their rights and interests by way of an action for protection of personal integrity , nor that ORG had required them to do so for the purposes of exhaustion of ordinary remedies under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . In the judgments mentioned in the preceding paragraph , ORG held that a judicial warrant for monitoring telephone communications was not subject to appeal . It was not reviewable by the ordinary courts , upon which the warrant was binding .
The individuals concerned nevertheless had to have a remedy against the warrant DATE both in relation to the evidence obtained by the monitoring and the fact of the monitoring itself .

However , the individuals concerned could not seek a court order in respect of the fact of the monitoring itself before the ordinary courts , be they criminal or civil , in the context of protection of personal integrity .
